pr_title: Implement explode mode for regular jar.

timeline.message: fix explodeMode to maintain original project structure

timeline.bodyText: This should remain an instance variable (non-static), scoped and limited only to each individual instance. static means a global variable shared by every instance of JavaContainerBuilder.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText:
Should remain an instance method.
And note JavaContainerBuilder is a public API. Probably we don't want to expose this internal helper method.
Just asking: did we decide to use JavaContainerBuilder instead of JibContainerBuilder for some reason? It's fine if JavaContainerBuilder works, but just saying I believe it's a bit curated and limiting.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.message: add helper to JarProcessor to filter out files and revert changes to JavaContainerBuilder
order file paths by string values and test on order

timeline.bodyText:
I think this should be configurable and if not then use a temporary directory.
Potentially we could have a jib local build directory that we can pass in.
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText: Also FYI: generally speaking, we should close Closeable classes like TempDirectoryProvider, e.g., using a try-resource block.
replies.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Thanks for pointing this out.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: "Class-Path" -> Attributes.Name.CLASS_PATH
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText: Done:)
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText:
" " -> "//s+" for handling any kind of white space
I might also do classPath.trim() ?
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText:
May be a good idea. For example, here, I see people saying like

two spaces immediately following Class-Path:, a space at the end of [each] line, and one before each line, and finally an extra new-line at the end did the trick.

although I'm not sure if the Java API handles all these whitespaces correctly. Worth checking anyway.
replies.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Oh great point, added handling for any kind of white space and added extra spaces in the class-path field in the sample jar file  to make sure this is working.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: Do we have to fail here? Would this code path also handle the shaded jar style jars (which may not have Class-Path entries)?
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText: That's a good question. I didn't intend for this code path to handle shaded jars. It mainly focuses on regular jars, which require the class-path to be fully specified in order for it to work. We could try to intelligently determine what the dependencies are in the future implementations, but for now I decided to first check that the Class-Path was present before proceeding to the next steps. What do you think?
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText: Regular jars include one that doesn't have Class-Path. It's possible that many people will try a hello-world app (i.e, no dependencies), so I think we shouldn't fail.
replies.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Oh that's a very valid point! Okay I will remove this exception.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.message: use DirectoryWalker and don't check ordering

timeline.bodyText: Another option is ... isResrouceFile = isClassFile.negate(), which I think works better in this case.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Oh this is cool.
replies.author: loosebazooka

timeline.bodyText: How about "explodedJarRoot" or "localExplodedJarRoot"? tempDirectoryPath gives the impression that it's a directory for a callee to use as a temp storage.

timeline.bodyText: Assert before attempting layers.get(2). Otherwise, for example, if the code base accidentally changes to produce only two layer, we'll hit an index-out-of-bound error when attempting .get(2).

replies.bodyText: That's a good idea!
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -44,4 +51,77 @@ public void testDetermineJarType_standard() throws IOException, URISyntaxExcepti
     JarType jarType = JarProcessor.determineJarType(standardJar);
     assertThat(jarType).isEqualTo(JarType.STANDARD);
   }
+
+  @Test
+  public void testExplodeMode_standard() throws IOException, URISyntaxException {
+    Path standardJar = Paths.get(Resources.getResource(STANDARD_RESOURCE_DIR_WITH_CP).toURI());
+    List<FileEntriesLayer> layers = JarProcessor.explodeStandardJar(standardJar);
+    FileEntriesLayer classesLayer = layers.get(0);
+    FileEntriesLayer resourcesLayer = layers.get(1);
+    FileEntriesLayer dependenciesLayer = layers.get(2);
+
+    assertThat(layers.size()).isEqualTo(3);
+
+    // Validate classes layer.
+    // TODO: Validate order of file paths once
+    // https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/jib/issues/2821 is fixed.
+    assertThat(classesLayer.getEntries().size()).isEqualTo(10);
+    assertThat(classesLayer.getName()).isEqualTo("Classes");
+    List<AbsoluteUnixPath> actualClassesPaths =
+        classesLayer
+            .getEntries()
+            .stream()
+            .map(FileEntry::getExtractionPath)
+            .collect(Collectors.toList());
+    assertThat(actualClassesPaths)
+        .containsExactly(
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/META-INF"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/class5.class"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory1"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory1/class1.class"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory1/class2.class"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2/class4.class"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2/directory3"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2/directory3/class3.class"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory4"));
+
+    // Validate resources layer.
+    // TODO: Validate order of file paths once
+    // https://github.com/GoogleContainerTools/jib/issues/2821 is fixed.
+    assertThat(resourcesLayer.getEntries().size()).isEqualTo(9);
+    assertThat(resourcesLayer.getName()).isEqualTo("Resources");
+    List<AbsoluteUnixPath> actualResourcesPaths =
+        resourcesLayer
+            .getEntries()
+            .stream()
+            .map(FileEntry::getExtractionPath)
+            .collect(Collectors.toList());
+    assertThat(actualResourcesPaths)
+        .containsExactly(
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/META-INF/"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory1"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory1/resource1.txt"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2/directory3"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory2/directory3/resource2.sql"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory4"),
+            AbsoluteUnixPath.get("/app/explodedJar/directory4/resource3.txt"));
+
+    // Validate dependencies layer.
+    assertThat(dependenciesLayer.getEntries().size()).isEqualTo(3);

timeline.message: addressing comment suggestions. Code style fixes, custom temp directory path, add jar file with classpath being more spaced out

timeline.bodyText: Once a Closeable class is closed, it's permanently shutdown and not usable. So you should put the entire code that needs to use localExplodedJarRoot into the try-resource block.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText: Minor point, but Jib build plugins use non-capitalized name "classes" (as defined in JavaContainerBuilder.LayerType).
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: I added an enum for layer types, similar to what's being done in JavaContainerBuilder.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: ditto
timeline.author: chanseokoh
chanseokoh

timeline.message: remove exception for when no class-path is present and add tests to check for empty dep layer

timeline.bodyText:
You can remove this else branch if you initialize the variable on line 118 like List<Path> dependencies = new ArrayList<>();.
How about skipping adding the dependencies layer if it's empty? To be fair, it shouldn't matter, because I believe jib-core will drop any empty layers. But we can be conservative at this level too.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: That's good to know. Modified this to not add a dependency layer if there are no dependencies specified in Class-Path.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.message: modify variable names, fix try-resource block, don't add dep layer if class-pathnot provided

timeline.bodyText: I think an enum is unnecessary if this is only to define layer names. It looks okay to me to use the string literals in the code as before.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText:
Oh! I realized there's a problem. When TempDirectoryProvider is closed, all the contents (i.e., exploded jar) will be cleaned up. That is, nothing left when exiting the method. However, tar creating happens far later in jib-core. I guess this method should just use tempDirPath (should not be @Nullable), unless the method opts to use a system temp directory. Since the method can accept tempDirPath, maybe we should just use it.
And how about tempDirPath --> tempDirectory?
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText: Nit: can chain ...builder().setName("dependencies").
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText: what about a jar that contains no resources?
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText: Great question. For a jar that doesn't contain resources, the resources layer will only contain the manifest.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: Perhaps I should've brought this up before, I'm also curious if we should persist the MANIFEST.MF after exploding the jar. That manifest only applies when using a Jar. Does it make sense to filter it out when building container layers?
timeline.author: loosebazooka

replies.bodyText: That's an interesting question. If you remember, at least the Spring Boot launcher requires it. I think it reads the file from classpath. Maybe it's not a great harm to include it ATM and see if someone complains?
replies.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Along those lines- I decided to keep it, going off of what we've seen with Spring Boot. I couldn't find a particular reason to intentionally remove it so I left in for the time being? Although, the main cost I see is that we will be creating a resources layer just for the manifest if we have a jar with only classes.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: Any reason not using @Rule public final TemporaryFolder as we do in other tests?
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.message: Use TemporaryFolder and add test for jar with only .class files

timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think that's a good idea.
replies.author: mpeddada1

timeline.bodyText: super nit: I think this comment is obvious enough to be removed.

replies.bodyText: True, done.
